The '''Superconducting Super Collider''' ('''SSC''') (also nicknamed the '''Desertron'''<ref name="analog">{{cite web |authorlink=John G. Cramer |author=John G. Cramer |date=May 1997 |archiveurl=http://replay.web.archive.org/19971010114852/http://www.npl.washington.edu/AV/altvw84.html |archivedate=1997-10-10 |url=http://www.npl.washington.edu/av/altvw84.html |title=The Decline and Fall of the SSC |publisher=[[Analog Science Fiction and Fact]] Magazine |work=The Alternate View column |accessdate=2011-05-09}}</ref>) was a [[particle accelerator]] complex under construction in the vicinity of [[Waxahachie]], [[Texas]] that was set to be world's largest and most energetic, surpassing the current record held by the [[Large Hadron Collider]]. Its planned ring circumference was {{convert|87.1|km|mi}} with an energy of 20 [[TeV]] per beam of protons. The project's director was [[Roy Schwitters]], a physicist at the [[University of Texas at Austin]] and [[Harvard University]]. Dr. Louis Ianniello served as Associate Director.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa5348/is_200510/ai_n21380886/|title=In Memory of Louis Ianniello| work=JOM |publisher=Minerals, Metals & Materials Society |date=October 2005| accessdate=2011-02-25 }}(archived at BNET/FindArticles)</ref> The project was cancelled in 1993 due to budget problems.
==Development== The system was first envisioned in the December 1983 National Reference Designs Study, which examined the technical and economic feasibility of a machine with the design capacity of 20 TeV per beam. After an extensive Department of Energy review during the mid-1980s, a site selection process began in 1987. The project was awarded to Texas in November 1988 and major construction began in 1991. Seventeen shafts were sunk and {{convert|23.5|km|mi|abbr=on}} of tunnel were bored by late 1993.<ref>{{cite web| author=Staff, Wire services |date=December 29, 2009 |url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/humaninterest/qampa-texas-supercollider-project-scrapped/1062063 |title=Q & A: Texas supercollider project scrapped |work=tampabay.com |publisher=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |accessdate=2010-07-11}}</ref>
==Cancellation== During the design and the first construction stage, a heated debate ensued about the high cost of the project. In 1987, Congress was told the project could be completed for $4.4 billion, and it gained the enthusiastic support of [[Speaker (politics)|Speaker]] [[Jim Wright]] of nearby [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth]].<ref>Jim Riddlesperger of [[Texas Christian University]], "Jim Wright", [[West Texas Historical Association]] and [[East Texas Historical Association]], joint meeting in [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth]], [[Texas]], February 26, 2010.</ref>{{Dubious|date=July 2010}} By 1993, the cost projection exceeded $12 billion. A recurring argument was the contrast with [[NASA]]'s contribution to the [[International Space Station]] (ISS), a similar dollar amount.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} Critics of the project argued that the US could not afford both of them. Early in 1993 a group supported by funds from project contractors organized a public relations campaign to lobby Congress directly,<ref>{{cite journal | title=Aggressive Promotional Blitz Aims To Shake SSC's Pork Barrel Image | author=Scott Veggeberg |journal=[[The Scientist]] | date = May 31, 1993 | volume =7 | issue=11 | pages=1 | url=http://www.the-scientist.com/article/display/16110/}}{{subscription required}}</ref> but in June, the non-profit [[Project on Government Oversight]] released a draft audit report by the [[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]]'s Inspector General heavily criticizing the Super Collider for its high costs and poor management by officials in charge of it.<ref name="MilwaukeeJournal">{{cite news | title=Super Collider's first collision is with auditors | author = Wire Services | date=June 23, 1993 | publisher = [[The Milwaukee Journal]] | accessdate=2010-06-29 | page=A9 | url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7aIaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=piwEAAAAIBAJ&dq=project%20on%20government%20oversight&pg=6784%2C6938021}}</ref><ref>[http://www.pogo.org/pogo-files/reports/contract-oversight/the-superconducting-super-colliders-super-excesses/co-ca-19930101.html The Superconducting Super Collider's Super Excesses]. ''POGO.org''; Project on Government Oversight.</ref>
[[Image:Sscmap1.jpg|thumb|A high-level schematic of the lab landscape during the final planning phases.]][[United States Congress|Congress]] officially canceled the project October 21, 1993.<ref name="Sun-Journal">{{cite news | title=Congress officially kills collider project| author=Michelle Mittelstadt, (AP)| date=October 22, 1993 |page = 7 |publisher=[[Sun Journal (Lewiston)]] |location=Lewiston, MN | accessdate=2010-06-28 |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kGAgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=umUFAAAAIBAJ&dq=cost%20overrun%20ssc&pg=3808%2C4981568}}</ref> Many factors contributed to the cancellation: rising cost estimates; poor management by physicists and [[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]] officials; the end of the need to prove the supremacy of American science with the collapse of the [[Soviet Union]]; belief that many smaller scientific experiments of equal merit could be funded for the same cost; Congress's desire to generally reduce spending; the reluctance of Texas Governor [[Ann Richards]];<ref>{{cite web |author= Alvin W. Trivelpiece |title=Some Observations on DOE's Role in Megascience |publisher=History of Physics Forum, [[American Physical Society]] |year=2005 |url=http://meetings.aps.org/Meeting/APR05/Event/30845 <!--http://www.aps.org/units/fhp/FHPnews/loader.cfm?url=/commonspot/security/getfile.cfm&PageID=67517-->| format=PDF |accessdate=2010-07-11}} Trivelpiece recounts hearing "about a conversation between the Governor of Texas, the Honorable Ann Richards, and President Clinton early in his administration. He asked her if she wanted to fight for the SSC. She said no. That meant it would no longer be an administration imperative."{{subscription required}}</ref> and President [[Bill Clinton]]'s initial lack of support for a project begun during the administrations of Richards's predecessor, [[Bill Clements]], and Clinton's predecessors, [[Ronald Reagan]] and [[George H. W. Bush]]. However, in 1993, Clinton tried to prevent the cancellation by asking Congress to continue "to support this important and challenging effort" through completion because "abandoning the SSC at this point would signal that the United States is compromising its position of leadership in basic science".<ref>{{cite web |author=President [[Bill Clinton]] |title=Letter to William H. Natcher, Chairman of the House Committee on Appropriations |date= June 16, 1993 |publisher=High Energy Physics Center at FermiLAB |work=HEP.net/ssc |url=http://www.hep.net/ssc/new/history/hepssc/clinton.html |accessdate=2010-07-11}} The letter reads in part, "As your Committee considers the Energy and Water Appropriations Act for Fiscal Year 1994, I want you to know of my continuing support for the Superconducting Super Collider (SSC). ... Abandoning the SSC at this point would signal that the United States is compromising its position of leadership in basic scienceâa position unquestioned for generations. These are tough economic times, yet our Administration supports this project as a part of its broad investment package in science and technology. ... I ask you to support this important and challenging effort."</ref>
The closing of the SSC had adverse consequences for the southern part of the [[DallasâFort Worth Metroplex]], and resulted in a mild [[recession]], most evident in those parts of [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]] which lay south of the [[Trinity River (Texas)|Trinity River]].<ref>{{cite journal |author = Jeffrey Mervis |date= October 3, 2003 |title = Scientists are long gone, but bitter memories remain |journal = [[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume = 302 |issue = 5642 |pages = 40â41 |accessdate=2010-07-11 |url = http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/search?volume=302&firstpage=40&search_citation-search.x=0&search_citation-search.y=0&search_citation-search=search | doi = 10.1126/science.302.5642.40 | pmid = 14526052}}{{subscription required}}</ref> When the project was canceled, {{convert|22.5|km|mi|abbr=on}} of tunnel and 17 shafts to the surface were already dug, and nearly two billion dollars had already been spent on the massive facility.<ref>{{cite journal |author = Jeffrey Mervis |coauthors = [[Charles Seife]] |date= October 3, 2003 |title = Lots of reasons, but few lessons |journal = Science |volume = 302 |issue = 5642 |pages = 38â40 |url = http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/search?volume=302&firstpage=38&search_citation-search.x=0&search_citation-search.y=0&search_citation-search=search |doi = 10.1126/science.302.5642.38 |accessdate=2010-07-11 |pmid = 14526051}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
== Comparison to the Large Hadron Collider ==
The SSC's planned collision energy of 40 [[Electron volt|TeV]] was almost triple the 14 TeV of its [[Europe]]an counterpart, the [[Large Hadron Collider]] (LHC) at [[CERN]] in [[Geneva]].
The SSC cost was due largely to the massive civil engineering project of digging a huge tunnel underground. The LHC in contrast took over the pre-existing engineering infrastructure and 27 km long underground cavern of the [[Large Electron-Positron Collider]], and used innovative magnet designs to bend the higher energy particles into the available tunnel. <ref>Info about the civil engineering cost and magnets is at [http://edgeofphysics.com/blog/its-the-magnets-stupid-why-the-lhc-succeeded-where-the-ssc-failed It's the Magnets, Stupid], Anil Ananthaswamy, edgeofphysics.com</ref>. The LHC eventually cost the equivalent of about 5 billion US dollars to build.
==Current status of site== [[Image:SSC panorama.jpg|thumb|right|View of the SSC site, 2008]]
After the project was canceled, the main site was deeded to [[Ellis County, Texas]], and the county tried numerous times to sell the property. The property was finally sold in August 2006 to an investment group led by the late [[Johnnie Bryan Hunt|J.B. Hunt]].<ref>{{cite web | author=Christine Perez | year = 2006 | month = August 18 | title = GVA Cawley to market former super collider | url = http://dallas.bizjournals.com/dallas/stories/2006/08/21/newscolumn6.html| publisher=Dallas Business Journal |accessdate=2010-07-11}} Collider Data Center, LLC.</ref> Collider Data Center has contracted with GVA Cawley to market the site as a tier III or tier IV [[data center]].<ref name="superconductorweek1">{{cite web| url=http://www.superconductorweek.com/pr/0806tgj/scsc1.htm |title=High Profile Superconducting Super Collider Project from Early 90's Sees New Life (press release)|author=GVA Cawley |publisher=Superconductor Week |date=August 16, 2006 |archiveurl=http://replay.web.archive.org/20090519005805/http://www.superconductorweek.com/pr/0806tgj/scsc1.htm |archivedate=2009-05-19 |accessdate=2010-07-11}}</ref> As of October 2010, the site is abandoned and run-down.
